I decided to do the "right thing" and let my manager know I was planning to transfer out. 5 minutes after that meeting, I was informed oops, you're actually flagged as underperforming and just haven't been informed of that in any way until now. Convenient. A few weeks later, I was given a PIP with impossible goals, so I took my severance and moved on. It was very clear to me that once I had no use for my manager, I was let go to avoid having to deal with finding someone else within the group to let go.

I am so much happier not being at Amazon anymore.

job_title: Senior Manager Product Marketing in Irvine, CA
pros: At Amazon you work with world-class talent, super smart, passionate and driven people all obsessing about how to help customers. Amazon has a very unique and strong culture where it's Leadership Principles guide day-to-day decision making in a highly visible way. Amazonians hold a high performance bar for each other and are encouraged to Think Big and take calculated risks. Working at Amazon is unique in that any manager regardless of leveling can make case for a new idea and if compelling in their argument, they will be supported to pursue the idea. Amazonians Dive Deep into data to identify insights and inform go-forward strategies. Amazon give it's employees the opportunity to do their best work while positively impacting the lives of millions of customers. Amazon also sets the bar in terms of allowances for employee leave for maternity/paternity or other health issues. I never saw an instance where an employee who needed leave or PTO was not fully supported.
cons: While the quality of the work product and innovation is incredibly high at Amazon, the level of effort and focus to maintain pace with the ever-increasing performance bar frequently impedes on one's personal life and requires frequent tradeoffs (sacrifices) for personal health and family/personal time. To maintain pace with the performance bar while supporting a load of weekly/monthly/quarterly deep dive business reviews, annual planning (ongoing for half the year), team development, strategic thinking and doc writing, (for most) requires working consistently through nights and weekends. Promotions at Amazon tend to occur 12-18 months after an employee has been operating at the next level and the process is equally as rigorous and challenging as getting hired. The company currency is the written narrative (6 pagers), be it a business review, new product idea or 3-year plan. These reviews can be anything but warm and fuzzy, one must have thick skin and high emotional intelligence to take criticism, which is widely constructive but can at times become demoralizing. Bottom line, Amazon isn’t for everyone and the pace and high expectations can lead to burnout; but if you have the stamina, customer passion, analytical horsepower and thick skin, it’s one of the best places to be to do your best work with some of the brightest minds you’ll meet.

pros: The training and onboarding plans are extremely thorough and employees truly embrace the leadership principles on a day to day basis. The continued employee experience is also emphasized quite a bit, you could spend a full 40 hours a week in webinars, learning sessions, and trainings for continuous development. In my experience I never feel like I'm playing politics which is really refreshing. People are direct, straight forward, engaged, and excited to contribute. Colleagues across departments in AWS are friendly and always willing to spend time with you, and I've been shocked at how well my team respects work/life balance and schedules especially in working with colleagues globally across different time zones. Even though levels are transparent, the culture is to treat everyone in more of an equal/flat structure, which is really healthy and creates a really positive employee experience from day 1 because your opinion matters, and you are hired in with respect. My department put a no-meeting Friday policy in place, and the team typically rarely asks folks to turn on video unless they are presenting which does make a remote day to day more manageable. It does prevent as much social interaction as I'd prefer, but it's coming from a really good place of creating boundaries and making people feel like they have a choice vs required to always be "on" remotely for show. The work is interesting and the high growth makes it really motivating to be a part of the team.
cons: It's definitely a professional environment so if you're looking for more of a fun, social group, you'll have to find that circle for yourself here. The team is making more of an effort in that way, and every group is different, but because the company is so large, spread out, and growing so quickly, there just isn't as much of an emphasis on camaraderie or social interactions. Most people are very appreciate once you reach out and spearhead a social event or conversation, but I find that I'm spending a lot of time with people that I don't really know anything about outside of our work. If you're looking to feel like an integral part of a social community in your workplace, be aware that you'll have to carve that out for yourself.

pros: We have a great team at my warehouse, so it's fun to show up. However, the work is incredibly physical - to the point you can only safely work half days unless you're 25 or younger. Good thing the shifts are only 4hrs long. There is a lot of opportunity for growth, they pay for your college so long as you go to one of their approved schools (none of which you've ever heard of). There are ample opportunities to take voluntary time off, which means no pay, but also no penalty to your accrued time off. As a part-time worker, you accrue 20 hours of unpaid time off every business quarter to be used at your own discretion. At my facility, at least, there is no judgement for doing so. My management team is great, and easy to work with and to work for. I enjoy the exercise of the job most of the time, but that's because I'm a full time student, so I'm sitting at a desk too many hours a day already. HR is very willing to work with you, and the people I've dealt with in all areas have been friendly and always aimed at working toward a positive outcome. Pay is above minimum wage, but since minimum wage is still below the poverty line, that's really not so spectacular in the real world.
cons: The work is incredibly physical - to the point you can only safely work half days unless you're 25 or younger. Loud environment. Hauling boxes all shift. ridiculously short break for the kind of work you do, and, frankly, it's not pay that respects the essential nature of the job. We're the guys getting your packages - food, meds, supplies, whatever - to you during a worldwide pandemic, in a country where people sometimes try to send explosives and anthrax through the mail. Think about that before you sign up. There have been periods when we got emails reporting positive CoVid cases everyday, if not two or more. While it's a diverse work environment, it's not great to be out LGBTQ+ (covert stuff not overt), but awesome with ethnic diversity, religious diversity, cultural diversity, abilities, etc. Point is, you'll really stress your body, you'll definitely be exposed to CoVid, you won't have health insurance unless you work double shifts regularly, you'll be putting your health and body at risk on a daily basis, and you'll only make $18/hr for it. Also, this company employed incredibly negative tactics to prevent unionization - both legal and illegal. Unionization is not something that is supposed to be under threat in this particular country, and is known to create better conditions for workers throughout history, so also consider that - not the question of unions, but the fact that this company would use such tactics against its front line workers to interfere with a protected right of American citizens and workers.

job_title: Principal Product Manager in Toronto, ON
pros: This is my third month at Amazon and I thought I would write a review of my experience. Amazon is a large MNC with over 1.5M employees worldwide. As such, there are micro cultures depending on what team/organization you join. I'm a corporate employee, and I can state that much of the stuff you hear in the media is not true. I have found that I'm surrounded by amazing colleagues you are smart and driven. There is a major focus on diversity and inclusiveness and many processes in place to reduce bias in hiring, day to day operations, promotions etc. My direct leader is very technical and engaged and manages by objectives (given targets to hit in terms of project deliveries). The pace of work is fast! You are expected to deliver results. There are weeks in which my work-life balance is negative and there are weeks my work-life balance is very positive. This is the nature of a technology role (irrespective of company). Overall, if you are good at what you do and can manage your time...I have found my work-life balance to be good. You will get what you put in. If you are dedicated to the job and the organization…you can really do well at Amazon. Ultimately, I'm working on cutting edge projects for arguably one of the top companies on the planet....its not easy but I can say that my job is absolutely rewarding! Did I make the right choice in joining Amazon? ABSOLUTELY!
cons: Large organization and it takes time to learn all the processes, teams, micro cultures etc. The ramp up period will be longer than other organizations because of the size of the organization and many cool projects that you will get to work on.
